Class PietsGrafieken.AffineTransformHelper

java.lang.Object
pietsgrafieken.PietsGrafieken.AffineTransformHelper
Enclosing class:
PietsGrafieken
public static class PietsGrafieken.AffineTransformHelper extends Object
This class creates AffineTransform in an easy way. An AffineTransform lets you easily switch from one coordinate system to another.

    • create

      public static AffineTransform create(Point2D ToTopLeft, Point2D ToBottomRight, Point2D FromTopLeft, Point2D FromBottomRight, boolean keepAspectratio)
      This method creates an AffineTransform that will help to translate between two coordinatesets. The coordinateset to which the inputcoordinates should be translated, is specified by two inputparameters: Point2D ToTopLeft and Point2D ToBottomRight. Likewise, the coordinatesystem from which the coordinates should be transformed are specified by two Point2D as well, and are called FromTopLeft and FromBottomRight. An example of its usage: say you have a JPanel with topleft coordinates (0, 0) and bottomright (400, 400). And say that we want to use usercoordinates in a rectangle (0, 1) (topleft) and (2,0) bottomright. Now, the aspectratio of both (height / width) differ: for the panel it is Par = 1, and for the userarea it is Uar = 1 / 2 = .5. If we do nothing about this, then a circle in userplane will become an ellips in the panel. There is a fifth parameter that indicates whether we should take this into account or not. This parameter is the boolean 'keepAspectratio. If true, then a circle in userplane will be a circle as well in the panel. the call is then as follows: var at = create(p2d(0, 0), p2d(400, 400), p2d(0, 1), p2d(2, 0), true); In 'main' an example is given
      Parameters:
      ToTopLeft - a Point2D indicating the topleft point of the TO area
      ToBottomRight - a Point2D indicating the bottomleft point of the TO area
      FromTopLeft - a Point2D indicating the topleft point of the FROM area
      FromBottomRight - a Point2D indicating the bottomright point of the FROM area
      keepAspectratio - boolean. If true then a coorection will be made in case of different aspectratios
      Returns:
      an AffineTransform to do the coordinate change

    • create

      public static AffineTransform create(double toLeft, double toTop, double toRight, double toBottom, double fromLeft, double fromTop, double fromRight, double fromBottom, boolean keepAspectratio)
      like the create constructor above, only the parameters are not points but the individual coordinates of these points The example given in the other constructor would be var at = create(0, 0, 400, 400, 0, 1, 2, 0, true);
      Parameters:
      toLeft - the left x coordinate of the TO area
      toTop - the upper y coordinate of the TO area
      toRight - the right x coordinate of the TO area
      toBottom - the bottom y coordinate of the TO area
      fromLeft - the left x coordinate of the FROM area
      fromTop - the upper y coordinate of the FROM area
      fromRight - the right x coordinate of the FROM area
      fromBottom - the bottom y coordinate of the FROM area
      keepAspectratio - if true, takes care that TO and FROM have the same aspectratio
      Returns:
      the correct AffineTransform

    • pixelsize

      public static double pixelsize(AffineTransform at)
      gives the pixelsize of a unit after AffineTransform 'at' is applied
      Parameters:
      at - the AffineTransform in question
      Returns:
      double number of pixels of one unit in 'at' coordinates use for instance: // g2d is the relevant Graphics2D, userToPanel is the AffineTransform that maps user coordinates to JPanel coordinates var pixel = AffineTransformHelper.pixelsize(userToPanel); g2d.setStroke(new BasicStroke(2 * (float)pixel));

    • createFontTransform

      public static AffineTransform createFontTransform(AffineTransform at)
      given an AffineTransform at, calculates another AffineTransform to be used in deriving a font tha is suitable for the scaling in at. Say, we have an at, and a font f. Now, the usage is: AffineTransform atfont = AffineTransform.createFontTransform(at); fontToUse = f.deriveFont(atfont); and use fontToUse in your drawing routines
      Parameters:
      at - AffineTransform
      Returns:
      see above
